com.github.valid8j.fluent

Enum Expectations

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<Expectations>
      • com.github.valid8j.fluent.Expectations
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<Expectations>

    public enum Expectations
extends Enum<Expectations>

    A facade class for the "fluent" style programming model of valid8j library.

    Following is an example for "overhead-less precondition checking for DbC style programming".

    public class DbC {
  public void aMethod(int a) {
    assert Expectations.precondition(Expectations.that(a).satisfies().greaterThan(0).lessThan(100));
  }
}

    Then, do static import to improve readability.

    public class DbC {
  public void aMethod(int a) {
    assert precondition(that(a).satisfies().greaterThan(0).lessThan(0));
  }
}

    Static methods in this class are designed so that the readability will become the best when they are static imported.

    An example for a test assertion looks like following.

    public class TestClass {
  @Test
  public void aTestMethod() {
    assertStatement(that(a).satisfies().isGreaterThan(0).isLessThan(100));
  }
}

    Also, note that that methods and value methods are synonyms to each others. Use one which maximizes your code’s readability.

        for (Expectations c : Expectations.values())
    System.out.println(c);

        public static Expectations valueOf(String name)

        Parameters:

        NullPointerException - if the argument is null

      • all

        public static boolean all(Statement<?>... statements)

        Checks if all the given statements are satisfied.

        Otherwise, this method throws an exception whose message describes what happened (how expectations are not satisfied.) This method is supposed to be used with assert statement of Java and when:

        • yor are checking invariant conditions in DbC ("Design by Contract") approach.

        • you are not interested in DbC approach.

        Parameters:
        statements - Statements to be asserted.
        Returns:
        true if all the statements are satisfied.

      • $

        public static boolean $(Statement<?>... statements)

        A "singular" version of all(Statement[]).

        Prefer this method if you only have one statement to be asserted. This method is supposed to be used with assert statement of Java and when:

        • yor are checking invariant conditions in DbC ("Design by Contract") approach.

        • you are not interested in DbC approach.

        Parameters:
        statements - to be evaluated by assert statement of Java.
        Returns:
        true if all the given statements are satisfied.
        See Also:
        all(Statement[])

      • expect

        public static <T> T expect(Statement<T> statement,
                           Function<String,Throwable> otherwise)

        A method to validate a value held by the given statement. If the value satisfies a predicate of the statement, it will be returned. Otherwise, an exception created by otherwise will be thrown.

        public class ExpectExample {
  public void method(String givenName, String familyName) {
    var firstName = expect(that(givenName).satisfies().notNull(), MyException::new);
    // ...
  }
}

        This method doesn’t have a plural version. Use fail( Function) method, instead.

        Type Parameters:
        T - A type of value to be validated.
        Parameters:
        statement - A statement to be validated.
        Returns:
        The target value held by statement.
        See Also:
        Statement, fail(Function)

      • fail

        public static Expectations.Unless fail(Function<String,Throwable> fail)

        This method is useful to specify an exception class to be thrown on a failure.

        public class FailUnless {
  public void method(int i, String message) {
    fail(MyException::new).unless(
      that(i).satisfies().greaterThan(0),
      that(message).satisfies().notNull());
    // or
    String price = fail(MyException::new).unless(that(i).lessThan(1_000_000));
  }
}
        Parameters:
        fail - A function that creates an exception from a given error message.
        Returns:
        An instance of `Expectations.Unless interface.

      • requireArguments

        public static void requireArguments(Statement<?>... statements)

        Checks if the target values of statements satisfy the predicates held by the statements as argument values. By default, this method throws an IllegalArgumentException on a failure.

        Parameters:
        statements - statements to be validated.

      • requireArgument

        public static <T> T requireArgument(Statement<T> statement)

        Checks if the target value of statement satisfies the predicate held by the statement as an argument value. By default, this method throws an IllegalArgumentException on a failure.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the target value of the statement.
        Parameters:
        statement - statement to be validated.
        Returns:
        The target value of statement.

      • requireStates

        public static void requireStates(Statement<?>... statements)

        Checks if the target values of statements satisfy the predicates held by the statements as state. By default, this method throws an IllegalStateException on a failure.

        Parameters:
        statements - statements to be validated.

      • requireState

        public static <T> T requireState(Statement<T> statement)

        Checks if the target value of statement satisfies the predicate held by the statement as a state value. By default, this method throws an IllegalStateException on a failure.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the target value of the statement.
        Parameters:
        statement - statement to be validated.
        Returns:
        The target value of statement.

        public static <T,TX extends Transformer<TX,V,T,T>,V extends Checker<V,T,T>> TX that(T value,
                                                                                    Function<T,TX> transformerFactory)

        Returns a transformer to build a statement for the given value. The transformer is created by a given transformerFunction. This method is called by the other that(value) methods and exposed as an entry-point for a user-defined custom transformer.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the value.
        TX - The type of the transformer.
        V - The type of the
        Parameters:
        value - A value to be validated.
        transformerFactory - A function that creates
        Returns:
        A transformer used for the validation.
        See Also:
        Expectations.CustomTransformer

      • satisfies

      • assertStatement

        public static <T> void assertStatement(Statement<T> statement)

        Fluent version of TestAssertions.assertThat(Object, Predicate).

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the value to be verified which a given statement holds.
        Parameters:
        statement - A statement to be verified

      • assertAll

        public static void assertAll(Statement<?>... statements)

        Fluent version of TestAssertions.assertThat(Object, Predicate). Use this method when you need to verify multiple values.

        You can use assertStatement(Statement), if you have only one statement to be verified, for readability’s sake.

        Parameters:
        statements - Statements to be verified
        See Also:
        assertStatement(Statement)

      • assumeStatement

        public static <T> void assumeStatement(Statement<T> statement)

        Fluent version of TestAssertions.assumeThat(Object, Predicate).

        Parameters:
        statement - A statement to be verified

      • assumeAll

        public static void assumeAll(Statement<?>... statements)

        Fluent version of TestAssertions.assumeThat(Object, Predicate). Use this method when you need to verify multiple values.

        You can use assumeStatement(Statement)}, if you have only one statement to be verified, for readability’s sake.

        Parameters:
        statements - Statements to be verified
        See Also:
        assumeStatement(Statement)
